title: I just watched a video about quantum entanglement and was wondering where we might find quantum entanglement in nature? - Quora

response.answer_text: Quantum entanglement first existed in the minds of Albert Einstein and Irwin Schrodinger; who coined the term in 1935, then spread throughout most of the physics community. It expresses the fact that throughout the timespan of quantum mechanical systems with only a few degrees of freedom, information is globally available that couldn't have been communicated at speeds ≤c. Nobody seems to have remembered in the succeeding 83 years that all fundamental physics, going back as least as far Newton, is deterministic: [1] the state of a solution at any moment determines the state at every moment throughout a solutions timespan. There's nothing to be communicated: any information present in a solution's state at some moment is present throughout the solution's timespan. The misconception persists because of a general lack of appreciation of the vast difference between time as we experience it and the undirected time of fundamental physics. Reversing t in any solution in fundamental physics gives an equally valid solution with time running the other way. That's not time as we experience it. We cannot affect our past, and we hold information only about our past. In 1926 Arthur Eddington called this vast asymmetry the Arrow of Time and in 1927 identified it with the direction our entropy increases. In 1865 Clausius defined entropy and reexpressed his and our universe's 2nd law of thermodynamics (Clausius 1850) in terms of it. The 2nd law can be stated as: the entropy of every closed system with enough degrees of freedom to yield unique well-defined entropy increases in the same direction in time. The Arrow of Time is universal in that sense. It also applies to open systems with sufficiently limited energy exchange with their surroundings, like rocks and people. Notice that the Arrow does not apply to systems with too few degrees of freedom to give unique well-defined entropy; such as the quantum mechanical systems that bothered Einstein: "spooky action at a distance", 1935; followed by Schrodinger's "quantum entanglement". It is true that in our universe any system with only a few degrees of freedom will be treated quantum mechanically, but it's their isolation: disentanglement if you like; from the surrounding entropic Arrow of Time that allows the underlying undirected time of fundamental physics to show through. For more details regarding entropy and the 2nd law in our universe, you might check my answer to What is the "arrow of time"? [1] For details about determinism in quantum mechanics, check my answer to What is the biggest mistake in the history of science?
